title: CORONA: High School evacuates after receiving bomb threat (UPDATE)
text:
BY ALI TADAYON, BRIAN ROKOS and ANNE MILLERBERND / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 20, 2015 Updated: 1:54 p.m. CORONA: High School evacuates after receiving bomb threat (UPDATE) Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 2 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Lee V. Pollard High School students stand outside of South Hills Church waiting to be picked up after a bomb threat prompted administrators to evacuate the school Tuesday, Oct. 20. BRIAN ROKOS/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER Related article Â» Pick-up location Parents of children who attend Lee Pollard High School can pick up their children at Souther Hills Church, 2585 South Main St. A Photo-ID is required to pick up your child.
Lee V. Pollard High School in Corona evacuated Tuesday, Oct. 20 after receiving a bomb threat.
Though the school day was cut short, nobody was injured, said Corona-Norco Unified School District spokeswoman Evita Gonzales.
"All are safe and accounted for," Gonzales said.
By 1:36 p.m., students with cars were allowed into the school's parking lot. School at that time had been let out for the day, following its normal bell schedule.
School administrators received the threat at 12:07 p.m., said Sgt. Paul Mercado of the Corona Police Department. The caller, who has not been identified, said there was a bomb on campus.
Soon after, Mercado said, administrators received another call. This time, the caller said the bomb would go off in 5 minutes. That's when administrators decided to evacuate the school to a nearby park.
At 1 p.m., the school remained closed as officers investigated the scene. Parents may pick up their children at South Hills Church at 2585 South Main St., Mercado said. A photo ID is required to pick up your child.
The Corona-Norco Unified School District sent out text message and voicemail notifications to parents, informing them of the situation, Gonzales said.
Corona resident Veronica Bender received a text alert from the school about the bomb threat, and went to South Hills Church to pick up her son, Justin.
Similar inicdents that have occurred recently in Corona left her asking questions.
"I'm just wondering what's going on with all these bomb threats," Bender said. Said she was happy they got the kids out of the school and across the street.
Larry Trejo, of Corona, went to South Hills Church Tuesday afternoon to pick up his granddaughter, Karen. He said he knows it's all for safety but that the way the school organized the pickup was a hassle.
He thinks the bomb threat was made by a student playing a practical joke.
Lee V. Pollard senior Maykenzie Verni was eating lunch when teachers started telling students to leave the lunchroom. The students stood outside of the school for a few minutes before going across the street to the church.
"I felt like the school could blow up at any minute, it was kind of scary," Verni said. "People like to mess around."
This story is developing. Check back for more information.
